Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Anti-Fouling and Anti-Scaling Slippery Surface Coating for Cleaning and Sanitation Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be the development of an easy-to-apply anti-fouling, liquid- and sludge-repellent coating aimed to reduce the water footprint, required cleaning frequency, and need for aggressive cleaning chemicals to maintain bathroom fixtures. Advanced ecofriendly technologies that enhance cleaning efficiency are highly sought after in janitorial services for large institutions and homeowners alike. Specifically, the household cleaners market size was valued at $5.79 billion in 2016 in United States, of which ~20% is toilet bowl cleaners that aim to remove bacteria and hard-water stains. From a societal perspective, we estimate that about 6.1 billion gallons of water is flushed down the toilet nationally each day - that is 2.2 trillion gal of water each year in the United States alone. Incorporation of this coating into bathroom fixtures, can significantly reduce the water footprint of bathroom fixtures. Viable low-flow or no-flow toilets may also help help address the open defecation problem affecting over 1 billion people globally.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop and investigate a new class of viscoelastic-repellent surface coatings with anti-bacterial and anti-scaling functions for cleaning and sanitation industries. Surface coatings that can resist bacteria and mineral fouling while maintaining both liquid and viscoelastic solid repellency are rare. The proposed project will investigate and quantify the coating design parameters required to significantly prevent the attachment of bacteria and mineral deposits, while remaining durable against mechanical abrasions under realistic operating conditions. This SBIR Phase I project will demonstrate that a sprayable surface coating not only can repel both liquids and viscoelastic solids, but can also resist fouling from bacteria and hard water stains without the use of aggressive chemical cleaners or excessive amounts of water. The best coating parameters identified in Phase I project will be considered for pilot tests in Phase II. The development of such a robust, non-fouling coating will offer significant reduction in the use of cleaning chemicals, flush water, and cleaning time, which has the potential to reduce costs associated with sanitation facilities maintenance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aimed to address the organic and inorganic fouling issues of toilet fixtures by developing a bacteria repellent and anti-scaling liquid and solid repellent surface coating. Current toilet surfaces are highly vulnerable to fouling from viscoelastic fecal matter, bacterial biofilms, and hard water staining. As a result, existing toilets need to be flushed with excessive water and cleaned frequently with disinfectants and aggressive chemicals to remove tough stains, waste residues, and accumulated minerals and bacteria. The goal of this project was the development and characterization of surface coatings that repel liquids and viscoelastic solids and that can resist bacteria attachment and mineral deposits in typical user environments. The commercial implications of achieving such as goal include reducing cleaning costs the need for aggressive chemicals and water.

 

The key results of this project include:

 

  • LESS coatings are significantly more effective at preventing bacteria attachment onto surfaces than conventional glass surfaces without cleaning chemicals. Specifically, surfaces treated with LESS (20 cSt) allow >99% reduction in bacteria adhesion compared to an untreated glass surface.
  • Surfaces treated with LESS (without any disinfectant) inhibit bacteria attachment almost as effectively as cleaning a surface with bleach. Specifically, the LESS treatment decreased adhesion by ~97% in this case, while the bleach addition (1:10, bleach:water) killed all bacteria.
  • LESS part 1 (i.e., base coat) is still more effective at preventing bacteria adhesion than uncoated glass. Specifically, LESS part 1 allows for a ~90% reduction in bacteria adhesion compared to untreated glass.
  • LESS coatings are more effective at preventing mineral scaling on glass than uncoated glass surfaces. After 100 hard-water rinse cycles, LESS-coated surfaces exhibited a >95% reduction in hard water buildup in terms of area coverage compared to untreated glass.
  • In static conditions, the sliding angle remains below 5º (using 15 uL droplet) over 8 months for all LESS-coated samples.
  •  In aggressive abrasive conditions (i.e., cycling 100 grit sandpaper over the surface with 2N normal force at 0.1 m/s), LESS part 1 (base coat only) is fully abraded after 200 cycles. LESS part 1 + part 2 (base coat + lubricant) can withstand >700 aggressive abrasion cycles.
